abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Orissa health systems
            development project were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: assess and address state
            and project management capacities; accountability was also
            important for results; develop local capacities to use fees
            collected; synchronize inputs to prevent delays; software
            activities like IEC should be initiated in the early stages
            of the project irrespective of the status of the completion
            of civil works; health care waste management is a behavioral
            change as it takes time and therefore constant training and
            monitoring is required by the project and the Directorate of
            health services to inculcate this behavior; district
            specific planning would seem to be more appropriate compared
            to a uniform set of activities being implemented across the
            state to improve health outcomes; prompt identification of
            problem status important for improvement; attention needs to
            be given to the provision of technical assistance (TA) and
            building of various capacities at the state and district
            levels; and engage further the private sector:
